Metadata: Effects of salinity on sperm motility, fertilization, and development in the Pacific herring, "Clupea pallasi"

This paper reports on the effects of salinity on fertilization and early development in a population of Pacific herring, "Clupea pallasi," that migrate from oceanic waters into the San Francisco Bay estuary to spawn. The salinity tolerance range for fertilization in "C. pallasi" is described; and evidence is provided that a synergistic effect between elevated Na+ and K+ ions at elevated salinities is responsible for decreased fertilization, due to an inhibition of sperm motility; and the effects of lowered and elevated salinity on embryonic development are determined.
